Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Magnetic components such as inductors and transformers are indispensable parts of commercial power supplies. Although they are often blamed as a hindrance toward higher power density, the magnetic volumes could actually be less than those occupied by the unused spaces and the product's housing. Converter size will shrink significantly if the discrete inductors and transformers are eliminated by integrating magnetic energy storage or functionalities into the housing and unused spaces. Since the housing is often realized by molding a protective, non-magnetic compound over the power converter, this project will pursue the innovation of incorporating a molding material that has magnetic properties. Molding such multifunctional material over the converter will form both the protective housing and the magnetic components, realizing "power integration by multifunctional molding ". Students affinity to new materials and to integration will be leveraged to share research opportunities and results with others. Construction of a multi-disciplinary engineering suite to realize the visions outlined above is expected to be a magnet attracting new undergraduates into electrical and material engineering and science, enticing juniors and seniors to graduate school, and promoting diversity. The engineering suite will serve as a campus test facility for laboratory experiments covering magnetic materials, molding resins, coupled magnetic fields, power-electronic circuits, and capstone design projects. "Scieneers," undergraduates in Virginia Tech's Scieneering program, will team with graduate research assistants to assist in simulation and experimental validation.

The objective of the research is to integrate energy-storage function into the encapsulating case of power module, thereby reducing material usage and possibly simplifying manufacturing process. Fundamental contributions are anticipated in materials and electrical engineering, education, and application. Encapsulation material that integrates mechanical/chemical (protective) and electrical (energy storage) functions are to be synthesized using low temperature and low pressure. Multi-magnetics module (MMM) with unexplored electromagnetic properties and design methodology are to be devised to take advantage of such material. Designability of power-electronic converters are to be assessed the presence of magnetic medium. Converter topologies are to be synthesized to leverage the field couplings inside an MMM. All fundamental advances are to culminate in a manufacturing process of multi-magnetics module with less materials and cost, possibly. In addition to the educational efforts noted above, point-of-load converters and battery chargers will be packaged into semi-assembled modules to be completed by the Center for Enhancement of Engineering Diversity's high school students in the summer as a part of Virginia Tech's effort to recruit and train engineers of diverse backgrounds.

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

POR.DRECONTENT:
In an effort to simplify the integration process of embedding magnetic components in power electronics circuits, moldable magnetic-alloy-polymer pastes with low curing temperature and no pressure were formulated, including: 1.Permalloy-Cobalt-based amorphous alloy (Metglas 2705M)-Trimethylolpropane triacrylate (TMPTA) pastes, 2.Permalloy-Sintered NiZn ferrite (Powdertech)-Trimethylolpropane triacrylate (TMPTA) pastes, 3. Permalloy-Sintered NiZn ferrite (3M FFDM)-Trimethylolpropane triacrylate (TMPTA) pastes.

The magnetic molding compounds met the requirement of moisture absorption, thermal properties (thermal conductivity and glass transition temperature) and mechanical properties (elastic modulus and CTE) and dielectric strength of commercial encapsulate. 

All bubble-free pastes can be solidified at 200? for one hour or at 120? for three hours without pressure. They can be processed by a paste extrusion 3D-printer. Complex permeability, core-loss density, and resistivity were measured. Permalloy-Sintered NiZn ferrite (Powdertech)-Trimethylolpropane triacrylate (TMPTA) pastes exhibited high relative permeability (µ’) up to 39 and high resistivity of 7.1*108 Ω?cm. Permalloy-Sintered NiZn ferrite (3M FFDM)-Trimethylolpropane triacrylate (TMPTA) pastes exhibited high relative permeability (µ’) of 35 and relatively low core loss density of 130 mW/cm3 with Bpeak of 10 mT at 1MHz, which is 67.5% lower than commercial iron powder core with the same relative permeability of 35 from Micrometals fabricated with pressure. 

Manufacturing of low-loss, multi-megahertz commercial ferrites requires high pressure and sintering in the vicinity of 1000oC. A gelcast ferrite paste was developed to fabricate ferrite core without pressure. The paste was applied to a commercial paste-extrusion 3D printer and printed out the T core as designed. The ferrite paste was also made into toroid cores to characterize complex permeability and core-loss density. Varying with sintering temperature, the relative permeability could range from 44 to 78. Core-loss densities were no larger than that of the commercial NiZn ferrite core 4F1 with a permeability of 80.

A dc-dc converter was employed to demonstrate the integration of an over-molded inductor (OMI) into a converter module. The impact of the OMI on converter's efficiency, operating temperature, and low switching noise was demonstrated to be similar to that of the commercial inductor. Also demonstrated was the feasibility of storing magnetic energy in the volume normally filled by encapsulant. 

Finite-element simulation and circuit simulation show the OMI module with an isolation layer (0.95mm) has almost the same efficiency as the commercial module with a discrete inductor and has higher power density and lower profile thanks to the multifuctional molding compound. The thickness of the isolation layer should be the same as the height of the bond to avoid storing unwanted magnetic energy in the modeling compound. 

Eleven graduate students were trained in materials and manufacturing processes. Five undergraduates participated between 2016 and 2019. The three engineering students continued to work with the PIs' research laboratories ever since. All three are applying for graduate school. Journals and conferences (including conferences and webinars organized by the PI's organization) have been the primary mechanisms for dissemination of results to the broader public. Technology details have been made available to 80+ industrial partners of the Center for Power Electronics Systems. A SPICE model for magnetic component taking into account phase shift between the windings, transient core loss, loss distribution under asymmetrical excitation, and fringing energy was delivered to industry. 

To spread engineering's research message to incoming freshmen, the PI participated in Virginia Tech's Student Transition Engineering Program (STEP). He hosted a small group of students and had one-one one conversation to expose them to engineering and research in magnetic materials and power processing. The PIMM research was demonstrated to about 20 faculty and students from Northwest Agriculture and Forestry University in China. Around 30 high school students from around the country toured the PIs' laboratory during the College of Engineering "Engineering Open House". These high school students were given more in-depth demonstrations and explanations of the current research. The PIs hosted tours for multiple groups of students from the local Blacksburg and Radford School Districts. These included tours for 6th graders from Belle Heth Elementary, as well as 7th and 8th graders from Dalton Intermediate School. In these tours approximately, 100 students toured the facilities and learned about novel technologies being explored and developed in NSF research. Fundamental explanations of engineering principles, and the process of developing technology were demonstrated to the students.

Hyrel, an additive manufacturing company in Georgia, was collaborated to identify the parameters and process for 3D-printing a magnetic component. The old challenge of printing a power toroidal inductor was re-visited by four graduate students, one undergraduate, and three engineers at Hyrel. The team met in Atlanta in July 2019 and continued to communicate via emails and phone calls to identify the issues and develop the solutions. Graphics of a toroidal inductor resulting from the collaboration were uploaded. A manual describing parameter settings and process developments for further components are available for new users.

  

 

 


Last Modified: 08/15/2019
Modified by: Khai D Ngo

Image
  • Toroidal core and winding can be additively manufactured without previous head and tail effects thanks to NSF-funded collaboration between Virginia Tech and Hyrel.
    Virginia Tech, Hyrel, NSF
    Khai D Ngo
    1507314resultApproachNgo

Addendum # 1

The project is completed.


Added: 11/29/2019
Submitted by: Khai D Ngo
